content: The Act titled "Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2015" establishes a pilot program to provide educational assistance to physician assistants for employment at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Grow Our Own Directive" pilot program, established by the Act of 2015, offers educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience. The pilot program, established by the Act of 2015, offers educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience and relevant healthcare training. The pilot program, established by the Act of 2015, offers educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience and relevant healthcare training. The program will run for five years, with the Secretary selecting at least 250 individuals to participate, giving priority to those who participated in a previous Intermediate Care Technician Pilot Program. The Secretary gives priority to individuals who participated in the Intermediate Care Technician Pilot Program between January 2011 and February 2015, and those who agree to work as physician assistants in medically underserved communities with a high veteran population. The Secretary prioritizes individuals from the Intermediate Care Technician Pilot Program and those willing to work as physician assistants in underserved areas with a high veteran population. The pilot program provides educational assistance for obtaining a master's degree in physician assistant studies. The Secretary will provide scholarships for individuals to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies or similar programs. At least 35 scholarships will be given each year under the pilot program. The Secretary will utilize existing educational assistance programs for this purpose. Under the pilot program, less than 35 scholarships are provided annually to individuals who agree to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service. Under the pilot program, individuals must fulfill a specified period of obligated service, which is determined based on the program they are participating in. Failure to meet this obligation may result in liability. An individual who fails to meet the obligated service period in the pilot program will be liable to the United States for the amount paid or payable to them, with the liability reduced based on the days served. The pilot program participant's liability for not meeting the obligated service period is determined based on the days served. Physician assistant mentors are available at Veterans Health Administration facilities for program participants. The Secretary aims to partner with at least 15 institutions offering a master's degree program in physician assistant education. The Secretary aims to partner with at least 15 institutions of higher education offering a master's degree program in physician assistant studies for the pilot program participants. These institutions must guarantee seats in their program for eligible individuals and provide them with necessary information. The pilot program aims to partner with institutions offering physician assistant studies programs, provide admissions information to participants, collaborate with military transition programs, and promote the program to veterans and Armed Forces members. The Department of Labor oversees programs under chapter 41 of title 38, United States Code, to market and advertise a pilot program to veterans and members of the Armed Forces. The Secretary appoints a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants to oversee the pilot program and recruit participants. The Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants oversees the pilot program, recruits candidates, coordinates with participants, and provides information to eligible individuals. They may also work at a medical center of the Department. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, a physician assistant and veteran, is responsible for coordinating the needs of the pilot program, providing mentors to participants, and coordinating staff at Veterans Health Administration facilities. They may also work at a medical center of the Department. The recruiter, reporting to the Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, collaborates with various offices within the Veterans Health Administration to develop employment positions and mentors for participants in the pilot program. They may also work at a medical center of the Department. The administrative assistant, compensated at a rate not less than level GS-6 of the General Schedule, assists with administrative duties in the Office of Physician Assistant Services to ensure effective operations. The administrative assistant in the Office of Physician Assistant Services ensures effective operations and assists with administrative duties. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will submit a report on the pilot program's effectiveness in improving eligible individuals' ability to become physician assistants. The pilot program aims to improve the ability of eligible individuals to become physician assistants, particularly focusing on enabling former Armed Forces members to enter the physician assistant workforce and addressing the shortage of physician assistants in the Department. The Secretaries of Veterans Affairs, Labor, Defense, and Health and Human Services will identify modifications to the program as needed. The pilot program aims to improve the ability of eligible individuals, especially former Armed Forces members, to become physician assistants and address the shortage of physician assistants in the Department. The Secretaries of Veterans Affairs, Labor, Defense, and Health and Human Services will identify necessary modifications to meet program goals and assess its potential as a model for other Department programs. At least $8,000,000 for the pilot program will be sourced from existing Department of Veterans Affairs appropriations. Establishment of standards for the Department of Veterans Affairs to use educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish standards to improve the use of educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants within the Department. Directors of medical centers will be held accountable for utilizing these programs to advance employees' education and enhance recruitment and retention of physician assistants. The Department of Veterans Affairs will implement programs and incentives to advance education for physician assistants and improve recruitment and retention. This includes making the Education Debt Reduction Program available for participants in a pilot program to fill vacant positions, by including information about the program in vacancy announcements and informing applicants of their eligibility. The Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs will implement regulations to advance education for physician assistants, including the Education Debt Reduction Program and monitoring compliance with educational assistance programs. Additionally, programs will be created to encourage employees to apply to accredited physician assistant programs. Establishment of pay grades for physician assistants of the Department of Veterans Affairs and requirement to provide competitive pay. The text discusses the establishment of pay grades for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs, including competitive pay and a national strategic plan for their retention and recruitment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a national strategic plan for retaining and recruiting physician assistants, ensuring competitive pay compared to the private sector. A report on the plan's implementation must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within one year of the Act's enactment.
